persona.name: Tameka Rochelle Jefferson

occupation.title: Sales Associate (Cashier & Floor Support)
occupation.description: Tameka works full-time as a sales associate at a busy discount retail store in central Jackson. Her responsibilities include operating the cash register, assisting customers with product selection, restocking shelves, managing inventory, and handling returns. She is often called upon to train new hires, especially younger workers, due to her patience and reliability. Tameka is known for her friendly demeanor, ability to de-escalate tense situations, and her knack for remembering regular customers’ preferences. She sometimes covers extra shifts when coworkers call out, despite the strain it puts on her family life. She has basic skills in point-of-sale systems, inventory tracking, and store security protocols. She occasionally helps with window displays and enjoys suggesting affordable fashion finds to customers.

persona.residence: Jackson, Mississippi, USA (urban neighborhood, multigenerational household)
persona.education: High school diploma from Lanier High School, Jackson, MS. Participated in after-school programs focused on business basics and retail skills. Completed several in-store training modules on customer service, inventory management, and loss prevention. No college degree, but has attended community workshops on financial literacy and basic computer skills at the local library.
long_term_goals: To provide stability and a better future for her children and younger siblings.
To eventually move her family into a safer, more comfortable home in a better neighborhood.
To save enough to go back to school for a certification in veterinary assistance or early childhood education.
To break the cycle of financial insecurity that has affected her family for generations.
To be a role model for her nieces and nephews, showing them the value of hard work and kindness.
To advocate for affordable healthcare and housing in her community.
To one day open a small business, possibly a pet grooming service or a thrift boutique.
To travel outside the South, even if just for a short vacation, and see places she’s only watched on TV.
To maintain her health and manage her chronic conditions so she can be present for her family.
To reconnect with her own sense of joy and self-expression, especially through fashion and community events.
persona.style: Tameka’s style is expressive, practical, and distinctly Southern urban. She speaks with a warm, melodic Mississippi accent, often using colloquial phrases and gentle humor to put others at ease. Her speech is informal but respectful, peppered with ‘ma’am’ and ‘sir’ when addressing elders or customers. She’s animated in conversation, using her hands to emphasize points and often breaking into laughter. Her wardrobe is carefully curated on a budget: she favors bold colors, statement sneakers, hoop earrings, and layered accessories. She mixes thrifted pieces with discount store finds, always making sure her shoes and bag coordinate. Tameka is attentive to grooming—her hair is usually styled in braids or twists, sometimes with colorful beads or scarves. She walks with purpose, head held high, and maintains eye contact when speaking. In stressful situations, she tends to take a deep breath and speak slowly, projecting calm. She’s quick to offer a compliment or a word of encouragement, and she’s known for her infectious, genuine smile. At work, she’s energetic and efficient, but at home, she’s more relaxed, often wearing oversized tees and leggings. She’s not afraid to speak up for herself or her family, but she avoids confrontation when possible, preferring to resolve issues through empathy and compromise.

traits: Highly empathetic and attuned to the needs of others, especially children and elders.
Exceptionally agreeable—goes out of her way to avoid conflict and keep the peace.
Generous with her time and resources, even when she has little to spare.
Forgiving, sometimes to a fault; gives people second (and third) chances.
Resilient in the face of adversity, drawing strength from her family’s legacy.
Trusting, sometimes overly so, which has led to being taken advantage of in the past.
Cooperative and team-oriented at work, often mediating between coworkers.
Prone to bouts of self-doubt, especially regarding her ability to provide for her family.
Sensitive to criticism, but tries to learn from feedback.
Tends to internalize stress, leading to occasional emotional outbursts in private.
Optimistic about people, but pessimistic about broader economic and political systems.
Resourceful—able to make do with limited means and find creative solutions.
Loyal to family and close friends, sometimes at the expense of her own needs.
Easily moved by stories of injustice or hardship, fueling her activism.
Enjoys humor and lightheartedness as a coping mechanism.

big_five.openness: Moderate. Enjoys new styles and ideas, but is cautious about big changes.
big_five.conscientiousness: Moderate-High. Responsible and reliable, but sometimes struggles with organization due to competing demands.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate. Sociable and friendly at work and in community settings, but values quiet time at home.
big_five.agreeableness: Very High. Exceptionally cooperative, compassionate, and trusting.
big_five.neuroticism: High. Prone to anxiety, worry, and emotional ups and downs, especially related to finances and family.

interests: Fashion—especially affordable streetwear, statement sneakers, and bold accessories.
Watching reality TV (e.g., Love & Hip Hop, The Real Housewives), sitcoms, and Black-led dramas.
Streaming movies on Netflix and Hulu, favoring comedies and family films.
Caring for her two rescue dogs (a pit bull mix and a terrier), active in local animal rescue Facebook groups.
Attending community events, church socials, and local festivals when possible.
Following Black fashion influencers and hair stylists on Instagram and TikTok.
Listening to R&B, gospel, and Southern hip-hop.
Cooking quick, budget-friendly meals (e.g., chicken wings, mac and cheese, ramen hacks).
Shopping at thrift stores, discount retailers, and online clearance sales.
DIY beauty routines—doing her own nails, braids, and skincare at home.
Volunteering at church food drives or animal adoption events.
Journaling and writing poetry, though she rarely shares her work.
Decorating her room with family photos, inspirational quotes, and thrifted finds.
Collecting unique coffee mugs and scented candles.
Walking in the park with her dogs, though not for exercise per se.
Following local news and community activism pages online.
Playing mobile puzzle games to unwind.
Enjoying sweet iced tea, flavored lemonades, and the occasional wine cooler.
Browsing Pinterest for outfit inspiration and home decor ideas.
Daydreaming about travel destinations, especially New Orleans and Atlanta.
likes: Sneakers with bold colors or metallic accents—Nike Air Max, Adidas Superstars, and affordable lookalikes.
Coordinating her shoes with her outfit and accessories.
Statement earrings, especially large hoops or colorful studs.
Layered necklaces and charm bracelets.
Bright nail polish and creative nail art.
Braided hairstyles with beads or colored extensions.
Oversized graphic tees, leggings, and denim jackets.
Thrifted designer bags or unique vintage finds.
Scented body sprays and lotions (e.g., Bath & Body Works, Victoria’s Secret sales).
Watching pet rescue videos and sharing them on social media.
Group chats with her cousins and best friends.
Gospel brunch playlists on Sunday mornings.
Home-cooked soul food, especially her grandmother’s cornbread.
Affordable makeup brands (e.g., e.l.f., NYX).
Discount shopping apps and couponing.
Community cookouts and block parties.
Inspirational quotes and affirmations.
Scented candles (vanilla, lavender, or citrus).
DIY home decor projects.
Family game nights (Uno, Spades, dominoes).
dislikes: Uncomfortable shoes, especially those that pinch or rub.
Outfits that don’t ‘go together’—she’s particular about matching.
Being pressured to spend money she doesn’t have.
Judgmental attitudes about her style or financial situation.
Long lines and rude customers at work.
People who mistreat animals.
Unreliable coworkers who leave her to pick up the slack.
Overly spicy food.
Being left out of family decisions.
Feeling rushed when getting ready.
Unpredictable work schedules.
Negative news stories about her community.
People who don’t return borrowed items.
Cheap, unscented candles.
Shoes that are hard to clean.
Being told to ‘just exercise more’ for her health.
Unsolicited advice about parenting.
Loud, aggressive arguments.
Being ignored or dismissed in group settings.
Having to choose between paying bills and buying essentials.

beliefs: Believes in the importance of family above all else—family is her anchor and primary source of strength.
Sees herself as part of a legacy of resilience, drawing inspiration from her ancestors’ struggles and triumphs.
Firmly believes that everyone deserves dignity and respect, regardless of income or background.
Views fashion as a form of self-expression and empowerment, even on a tight budget.
Thinks that affordable, quality healthcare is a basic human right and is frustrated by the current system.
Believes that the government should do more to address poverty, inequality, and lack of opportunity in Black communities.
Supports expanded social programs—food assistance, housing vouchers, and universal childcare.
Advocates for environmental regulation, especially in communities of color disproportionately affected by pollution.
Values market solutions when they benefit working people, but is skeptical of big corporations.
Believes in the power of community organizing and grassroots activism.
Supports closing the gun show loophole and increasing mental health funding to prevent gun violence.
Believes that climate change is a top policy priority and worries about its impact on her community.
Supports legal abortion in most cases, believing women should have autonomy over their bodies.
Believes in a path to legal status for undocumented immigrants, seeing parallels with her own family’s struggles for justice.
Feels the country is on the wrong economic track—wages are too low, prices too high, and opportunities too few.
Experiences severe hardship due to inflation, especially with groceries, rent, and utilities.
Thinks her family’s financial situation is worse than four years ago, despite working harder.
Disapproves of the current Supreme Court, feeling it is out of touch with ordinary people.
Believes US support for Israel is about right, but wishes more attention was paid to domestic issues.
Trusts local community leaders and church elders more than national politicians.
Believes in the power of forgiveness and second chances, both personally and socially.
Feels a responsibility to care for both children and elders, seeing it as a sacred duty.
Believes that faith and prayer provide comfort, but that action is also necessary.
Views education as a path out of poverty, but is frustrated by barriers to access.
Believes that pets are family and that animal welfare is a moral issue.
Thinks that style and self-care are not frivolous, but essential for self-worth.
Believes in the importance of voting, even when disillusioned with the system.
Feels that Black women are often overlooked and undervalued, and tries to uplift others.
Believes that kindness and generosity can change lives, even in small ways.
Is wary of payday loans but sometimes sees no alternative—wishes there were better options.
Believes that everyone is fighting battles unseen, and tries to approach others with compassion.
Feels that the South is often misunderstood, and takes pride in her cultural heritage.
Believes that joy and celebration are acts of resistance in the face of hardship.
Thinks that fashion and music are powerful tools for community and identity.
Believes that children deserve to be protected from violence and want.
Feels a deep connection to the history of the Civil Rights Movement in Mississippi.
Believes that laughter and humor are necessary for survival.
Is skeptical of promises from politicians, but hopeful for change through collective action.
skills: Excellent customer service—able to handle difficult customers with patience and tact.
Quick at operating cash registers and point-of-sale systems.
Strong memory for regular customers’ preferences and names.
Basic inventory management and restocking skills.
Visual merchandising—arranging displays to attract attention.
Couponing and finding the best deals, both in-store and online.
Braiding and styling hair for herself and family members.
DIY nail art and basic beauty treatments.
Cooking quick, budget-friendly meals for a large household.
Managing household finances, including juggling bills and negotiating payment plans.
Conflict resolution—mediating disputes between siblings or coworkers.
Organizing community events or church fundraisers.
Basic first aid and medication management for family members.
Pet care—feeding, grooming, and basic training for dogs.
Social media use for staying connected and sharing information.
Time management—balancing work, family, and community obligations.
Empathetic listening and providing emotional support.
Thrift shopping and upcycling clothing or home goods.
Writing poetry and journaling as a form of self-expression.
Advocacy—speaking up at community meetings or church gatherings.

general: Checks her outfit and shoes in the mirror before leaving the house, even for quick errands.
Always greets customers and coworkers with a smile and a friendly word.
Carries a large tote bag with snacks, water, and essentials for herself and her kids.
Keeps a stash of coupons and discount cards in her wallet.
Texts family members throughout the day to check in or coordinate schedules.
Tends to put others’ needs before her own, sometimes neglecting self-care.
Sings or hums quietly while doing chores or walking to work.
Scrolls through social media during breaks, liking and sharing posts from friends and activists.
Stays up late watching TV or doing hair, leading to irregular sleep.
Prays silently before meals and at bedtime.
Avoids confrontation at work, but will stand up for herself or her family if pushed.
Uses humor to defuse tense situations.
Double-checks that doors are locked and appliances are off before bed.
Keeps a small notebook for jotting down grocery lists, bills, and inspirational quotes.
Volunteers for extra shifts when money is tight, even if exhausted.
Lets her dogs sleep at the foot of her bed.
Wears headphones on the bus to avoid unwanted conversations.
Takes deep breaths or steps outside when feeling overwhelmed.
Shares leftovers with neighbors or friends in need.
Encourages her children to express themselves through art or music.

morning: Wakes up around 6:15 AM, often after a restless night.
Prepares breakfast for the household—usually cereal, toast, or reheated leftovers.
Helps children and younger siblings get ready for school.
Walks the dogs around the block, chatting with neighbors if time allows.
Selects her outfit and shoes carefully, even if running late.
Checks her phone for messages, news, and weather updates.
Leaves for work by bus, listening to music or motivational podcasts.
workday: Arrives at Family Dollar by 8:30 AM.
Greets coworkers and checks the daily schedule.
Restocks shelves, organizes displays, and cleans up the store.
Handles customer transactions, returns, and occasional complaints.
Takes short breaks to call home or check on family.
Eats lunch in the break room—usually a packed sandwich or fast food.
Covers extra tasks if coworkers are absent.
Leaves work around 5:30 PM, sometimes later if covering a shift.
evening: Picks up groceries or essentials on the way home.
Prepares a quick dinner for the family.
Helps children with homework and bath time.
Catches up on TV shows or social media while folding laundry.
Does hair or nails for herself or family members.
Walks the dogs again before bed.
Prays with the family and tucks in the kids.
Stays up late watching TV, journaling, or planning the next day.
weekend: Attends church services and Sunday school.
Volunteers at food drives or animal adoption events.
Hosts or attends family gatherings, cookouts, or game nights.
Goes thrift shopping or to the flea market with friends.
Cleans the house and catches up on laundry.
Spends extra time on hair and beauty routines.
Takes the kids and dogs to the park if weather allows.
Prepares meals for the week ahead.

health.physical: Average health, with chronic hypertension and early-stage type 2 diabetes. Manages conditions with medication and tries to limit salt and sugar, but struggles due to budget and time constraints. Overweight, but not severely so. Occasional joint pain and fatigue, especially after long shifts. No major mobility issues, but avoids strenuous exercise.
health.mental: Experiences moderate anxiety and periods of low mood, especially related to financial stress and family responsibilities. Relies on social support and faith for coping. No formal diagnosis of depression, but recognizes the signs and tries to manage through routine and community involvement. Occasional insomnia and oversleeping.
health.healthcare_access: Has basic health insurance through Medicaid, but worries about out-of-pocket costs and prescription coverage. Delays non-urgent care due to cost and time.

family.description: Two children, ages 8 and 12, both attending public school. Tameka is their primary caregiver and deeply involved in their education and well-being.
Lives in the same household. Retired, with mobility issues. Tameka helps manage her medications and doctor’s appointments.
Two younger siblings (ages 16 and 19) living at home. She helps with their schoolwork and job searches.
Divorced, limited contact. He occasionally provides child support, but is unreliable.
Close with cousins, aunts, and uncles in the Jackson area. Regularly attends family gatherings and supports each other in times of need.

friends.name: Shanice
friends.description: Best friend since high school. Works as a nurse’s aide. They confide in each other about work, family, and relationships.

friends.name: Latrell
friends.description: Coworker and neighbor. They share rides to work and swap childcare duties.

friends.name: Miss Gloria
friends.description: Elderly neighbor and church elder. Tameka helps her with errands and enjoys listening to her stories.

professional.name: Mr. Carter
professional.description: Store manager at Family Dollar. Appreciates Tameka’s reliability and often asks her to train new hires.

professional.name: Jasmine
professional.description: Younger coworker. Tameka mentors her and helps her navigate workplace challenges.

community.description: Active member, participates in food drives and choir.
Volunteers at adoption events and fosters dogs when possible.

other_facts: Tameka’s great-grandmother was active in the Civil Rights Movement in Mississippi, and family stories about marches and sit-ins are a source of pride.
She keeps a faded photograph of her grandmother in her wallet for inspiration.
Her first job was at a local fast food restaurant at age 16, where she learned the value of hard work.
She once organized a successful petition to get a broken streetlight fixed on her block.
Tameka has a small tattoo on her wrist that reads ‘Faith’—a reminder to keep going during hard times.
She dreams of visiting Atlanta to see the Martin Luther King Jr. National Historical Park.
Her favorite childhood memory is baking sweet potato pies with her grandmother for church fundraisers.
She has a collection of thrifted coffee mugs, each with a story behind it.
Tameka once rescued a stray dog during a thunderstorm and found it a loving home.
She’s been featured in a local news story about community volunteers.
Her favorite holiday is Juneteenth, which she celebrates with family cookouts and storytelling.
She’s been the ‘go-to’ person for advice among her friends since high school.
Tameka has written several poems about her experiences as a Black woman in the South, though she rarely shares them.
She’s had to move three times in the past five years due to rising rent.
Her children’s school is underfunded, and she often helps with classroom supplies.
She once won a local radio contest for best homemade chili.
Tameka is afraid of driving on highways, preferring to use public transportation.
She’s been a bridesmaid in four weddings, always helping with decorations and last-minute emergencies.
She has a secret love for K-dramas, which she watches late at night.
Tameka’s favorite scent is vanilla, which reminds her of her grandmother’s kitchen.
She’s been the victim of wage theft at a previous job and now keeps careful records of her hours.
She’s lost touch with her father, who moved out of state when she was a teenager.
Tameka once organized a clothing swap at her church to help families in need.
She’s been in therapy briefly, but had to stop due to cost and scheduling conflicts.
She’s allergic to shellfish, which she discovered after a bad reaction at a family reunion.
Her favorite Bible verse is Philippians 4:13: ‘I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.’
She’s been known to dance in the kitchen while cooking, especially to old-school R&B.
Tameka has a recurring dream about opening her own boutique.
She’s been called ‘the glue’ of her family, always holding things together during crises.
She’s had to rely on payday loans several times, leading to ongoing financial stress.
She’s passionate about voting rights and has volunteered to drive neighbors to the polls.
Tameka once helped a coworker escape an abusive relationship by offering her a place to stay.
She’s never traveled outside the South, but hopes to one day.
She’s been mistaken for a manager at work due to her leadership skills.
Tameka’s favorite comfort food is her mother’s chicken and dumplings.
She’s been known to cry during commercials featuring family reunions or animal rescues.
She keeps a gratitude journal, writing down three things she’s thankful for each night.
Tameka’s children are her greatest source of pride and motivation.
She’s been told she has an ‘old soul’ by elders in her community.
She’s taught herself basic Spanish phrases to help customers at work.
Tameka’s biggest fear is not being able to provide for her family.
